description: From Spanish maravedí, from Arabic مُرَابِطِين‎ (murābiṭīn), an inflected plural of مُرَابِط‎ (murābiṭ, “holy man”), the name of the Almoravid rulers of Muslim Spain during the 12th century. Compare marabout.

entries.meaning: (historical) A former Spanish coin and unit of currency, originally issued in gold but later in silver and copper, discontinued in 1848.
(figurative) A very small quantity or value; the least possible amount.
